Kingmaker is Owlcat Games' very first game and they nailed it. While this game is worth full price, I suggest waiting for a sale. Kingmaker goes on sale for about $3 all the time and at that price it's hard not to suggest this game!

[b]The good:[/b]
[list]
    [*]Solid companions and solid writing
    [*]Character creation is addictive
    [*]Good mechanics 
    [*]Nok-Nok 
[/list]

[b]The bad:[/b]
[list]
    [*]Some encounters are vastly harder than others and some will hard counter certain builds such as trip builds vs swarms/flying/etc.
    [*]Mostly minor bugs. I have only ran into one significant bug in my first full playthrough which was a recruitable companion not showing up when he was supposed to.
[/list]

My suggestions for the best experience: Try a few hours on Easy difficulty if this is your first CRPG and/or you have no prior knowledge of Pathfinder 1E. If this is not your first then try a few hours on Normal. Avoid Challenging and above difficulties for your first play through unless if you're stubborn. There is no shame in looking up build guides and the solution to puzzles if you don't care for Owlcat puzzles. Oh, and save frequently, one manual save at the beginning of each dungeon and quick saves before entering a new room.

The game adapts the tabletop Pathfinder ruleset into a lengthy CRPG about exploration and political leadership. You begin as an adventurer and progress toward ruling a growing kingdom. The narrative mixes dungeon crawling with regional management.

Character creation is dense. Classes, archetypes, feats, and spell lists allow deep build paths. New players may feel overwhelmed. Veterans can refine party roles for late-game encounters. Progression rewards system knowledge.

Combat is real-time-with-pause. Positioning, crowd control, and buff sequences influence outcomes. Enemy resistances and saving throws matter. High difficulty punishes unprepared parties. Timing and spell synergy carry weight.

Kingdom management adds a strategic layer. You assign advisors, handle crises, and develop regions. Poor management can cause collapse. The system adds consequence but can feel punishing. Events occur on strict timers.

The Enhanced Plus Edition improves stability, balance, and interface clarity. Loading times are shorter. Visual readability is better. Navigation through inventories and spell books shows less friction.

Audio is effective. Ambient tracks support wilderness zones. Voice acting highlights major conversations. Spell effects and creature sounds provide useful cues. Overall sound design is functional.

The game suits players who enjoy long CRPG campaigns that reward planning. Complexity is high but yields satisfaction. Kingdom management introduces stress but enhances immersion. Strong value for fans of tactical party building.

Of all the Owlcat games, this is the hardest to get through. 

It was and still is incredibly ambitious and borderline demented, but this ambition comes with drawbacks, many of which they only started to remedy in their more recent titles (WotR and Rogue Trader). It is incredibly long, to the point where the endgame is more of a marathon than a glorious climax. This marathon sadly extends to the gameplay as endless waves of trash fights, for which you still have to sort of min-max and buff up tho (thanks PF 1e), simply get boring and tedious after a while. 

Choices and consequences also suffer from the game lenght. Without more specialised RP options and world consequences, any alignment path besides Chaotic good will feel severely out of place and weird. The Mythic system in WotR did wonders to remedy this, but once again this is an example of a lesson learned from a non-functional aspect of Kingmaker. 

The endings are also severely undercooked and do not synergise between eachother, it is so bad I wouldve prefered a "You win" screen to what I got. This is a problem in all 3 Owlcat CRPGs to date, and I cannot pinpoint why it keeps happening. Fallout New Vegas did good and cohesive ending slides back in 2010, you dont have to re-invent the wheel here. 

So after all this, why the thumbs up? Well for one, as a product of its time, it is amazing and the sheer gravitas of this game being the springboard from which Owlcat began their rise into the CRPG game market is incredible. Taking something so niche, executing it so incredibly, painstakingly accurate that it actually becomes a detriment and still create a fun and engaging product is nothing short of awesome. 

The build variety is great (Although somewhat limited if one wants to play on anything higher than Normal), the scope of adventuring around and managing a kingdom at the same time feel good (IF IT WAS SHORTER) and some character arcs are legitimately cool, you can become attached to these people as well as your kingdom as a whole and Owlcat's writing definitely proved itself in their very first entry already. 

Sadly,  less than 10 % of the playerbase has the "you win" Achievement. Less than 10 % actually finished the game. This is somewhat expected, considering the niche nature of the game and it many non accessible aspects, but its still sad. In my opinion, no matter how niche, a game shouldn't be not finished by a large majority of players and I blame the lenght above anything. You can play the same Pen & paper campaign for many years, but this lenght, this maturing of story which comes naturally in IRL Roleplaying, cannot be translated to a videogame. 

I bet most people had fun for their first 30, 35 or even 40 hours, but just didn't have it in them to run the final 100 miles. In hindsight they didn't miss much, truely, but this problem with Owlcat games dragging on and simply not holding attention long enough started here with their very first release. WotR upped the completion rate to almost 12 % while rogue trader sits at roughly 17 %. They are slowly catching up the Behemoth of BG 3 with its almost 22 % completion rate, but neither has figured out a way to make most people see these long adventures through. 

TLDR: Digressions aside, Kingmaker is fun, but tedious. It is detailed but often sloppy. It is grand but often confusing. In the end only the biggest of CRPG fans will see the adventure through, but I like to see the game more as the beginning of a bigger adventure; the adventure of Owlcat games and their struggle to bring CRPGs and niche PnP games solidly into the mainstream. As an "Act 1" of this adventure, Kingmaker is well worth a recommendation.

After a long period of time when I basically only played JRPG's I decided that I needed a change of pace and, since it had been a long time since I'd played any isometric CRPG's I went back to play some of the gems I'd missed over the years. After playing Divinity: Original Sin 1 & 2, Pillars of Eternity and Baldur's Gate 3, I decided to give this one a try.

I'm happy to say I'm having fun with it and that it kind of feels like a middle point between Divinity and Baldur's Gate 3, since it does use the Pathfinder rules, that are based on the D&D open license, but it understandably lacks the high-end cutscenes and visual presentation of the newer game. It's not quite as complex as what Larian does, since their games are really detailed and give you a lot of freedom, but it doesn't feel as outdated and clunky as Pillars of Eternity did, despite the fact that it literally came out a year after the origianl Divinity: Original Sin.

The game is fun and feels like a newer version of the old Baldur's Gate games, but it does have its flaws, such as the annoying mechanics that have to do with resting and camping when your characters get tired, which happens all the time because the game is literally designed to make you travel from point A to point whatever a ton of times, and it has a glaring flaw with random encounters during those travels because you run the risk of stupid crap like running into a random battle with, say, a dozen greater elementals despite the fact that you're like level 5 and there's zero reason why from a story standpoint so many powerful monsters would be randomly roaming around together in some backwater road, so that if you run into that stupid encounter you're dead no matter what you do and you can't run away easily and you'll lose whatever progress you'd made since your last save. That's just B.S. and a terrible design choice that I'm amazed hasn't been fixed by a patch after so many years and full on gigantic sequel.

Other than that, I'm digging slowly building up my barony/kingdom in parallel of the usual adventuring, since the former usually involves making story-based decisions and managing resources, and the latter is the more traditional gameplay loop where you go out dungeon crawling and fighting monsters or bad guys. I also like that your companions can disagree with you and each other, and sometimes even choices that seem like the "correct" one from the traditional "good guy" standpoint might elicit an unexpected response from a companion that has some unique view regarding that specific issue regardless of what you'd expect from their alignment.

Edit: After 20+ hours and in the middle of Act 3 I screwed up because I was too busy running my kingdom and chasing timed companion quests and so on, and I realized I had 16 hours to get to the location of a main quest of the kingdom would be destroyed. Thing is, I was all the way to the other side of the map and it was impossible to make it in time so it was game over and there was nothing to be done about it except go back to a save file that has so old that I might as well start over again. I get it, it's on me, but it's still annoying and made me drop the game until I feel like trying again, which won't be in a long time.

The game is great. Loved the story, the characters and how they adapted the system to a videogame. Loved the antagonist a lot, and voice acting is crazy good. 
And I love, love the possibility to play as an evil dude. People react to your choices, and game changes. Not sure if I can (mentally) finish an evil run, but the sole possibility of it warms my heart.

But its not perfect, and here are some advices to new players:
1. Must-have mods are Bag of Tricks and Cleaner. You can find them on nexusmods.
2. Difficulty levels above Normal are actually hard. There is no shame in playing on normal or easier.
3. Raise kingdom stats early. You want them maxed out as soon as its only possible.
4. Resolve main quests first. After each major story event you will have some time to resolve kingdom issues. Do not act in the opposite order - some main quests, when delayed, will harm your kingdom. 
5. The game has a time limit. Do not be intimidated - there is plenty of it. Like, a lot. Just do not lose yourself in side quests completely.

Pathfinder is a funny thing. there is a lot of good and a lot of bad stuff to be said about this game ^^.
Most of the game is very much enjoyable. The voice over is mostly pretty good and the optics give a good old Icewinddale / Baldurs gate 2 vibe. Graphics for me a really okay and the story is actually pretty good. It definetely goes beyond " be the greatest hero of all time" and has more depth then the average "ur awesome"-rpg. i do not wish to spoil the story , but i enjoyed the story a lot so far, and it has allready become clear , daß you are able to make totally different choices on multiple playthroughs. Also having many many very different companions who most of them are really cool in my book , gives you a lot of different options to pick from. The companions are done really really nice, i enjoyed most of them a lot. 

While the game seems to be bugfree nowadays, which is great, there are a lot of technicalities about rules and infos that are sadly pretty bad even though many games before using pathfinder or D&D have done this very well. 
For example many talents in pathfinder (feats in english i believe) have prerequisites like certain attribute points and or other feats which need to be taken before. In the source books and or other games you can often or mostly see these. this makes it much easier to plan what kind of character you would like to build. 
Kingmaker does not have this and in all those years of its existence no one thought it to be a good idea to implement it , even if late. That means if you are not a total freak and know most of them out of the top of your head, or lo and behold if you are someone who likes roleplaying games but you do not know pathfinder, then u are royally screwed. And if you have to go through online pathfinder rulebooks for hours on end to build a somewhat decent charackter,  then i am of the opinion that the ppl who made this game did something wrong. 
On the other hand, when you finally get the gist of it playing is actually a lot of fun. the reason i critisize this so heavily is that there are many situations, where you will get totally wasted if ur characters are not at least in part maximized. That becomes even worse, when most of the characters that the game offers you as companions are the absolute opposite of an effective build. here another example. you will get a tank fighter which is intended as exactly that, a tank. but that charackter lacks enough inteligence to get some of the most important tank skills, which have a prerequisite of 13 intelligence (natural 13). In fact her int is so low it does not even make sense to improve it , because you would have to wait until L16 until you would have int 13. In addition to that, the game gives you advice on what talents to choose when you level up, but very often these advices are very very bad or in some cases they will even mark  some of the best picks as "do not pick, does not help". That is kind of mind blowing to me because it leads newcomers astray. And if you have ineffective charackters you will often come into a situaion, where the enemy spawns will totally wipe the floor with you. That is not cool. 
What is also not cool is, that with the system of building up your country/barony/kingdom you are thrown into the hot water. i for example allready assumed this was a big part of the game and watched about 3 hours or YT-vids and read 4 -5 handouts about it online, and i still had that moment when everything was going fine, that all of a sudden one quest fails , rebellion start instantly and after 10-12 days (that is not long in this at all) all of a sudden a window popps up saying : game over . you ruinied your lands try again. and i had no clue whatsoever how within 14 days my barony fell from stable to rebellious and game over. Again i had to turn towards the online community to get this solved even though i had an idea what it could have been, but the game itself told me shit.  All these things anger me. And while i could save my game by loading a savegame 2 weeks earlier this still sucked in my book. 
Much of the game feels like you are under a lot of time pressure. In all honesty that is not for me. i do not like that. i play to have fun not to get the feeling that i have to rush everything or the game is over. 

In the end that means you have to decide if the development of your lands and charackters and the story weigh in heavier then the artifical time-pressure and the lack of a lot of explanation. Sure once you have experienced it, u'll know , but i do not like games that are designed to shitcan you early on ,just so they can say: look how hard our game was , dang we did a hard game didn't we!" But not explaining anything or most of it is not a good difficulty level it is the opposite. 
so in the end the question is , would i recommend it. and i say yes. because while i did get frustrated early on a lot , in the end i still had a lot of fun and i kept playing even though i was very short of deinstalling it. 
But i recommend to only get this on a sale or if the full price does not bother you at all . i also advice on the complete edition ,because the addons fit in really well and you should have them.

Recommended WITH CAUTION. All in all I had a great time with this game but it has a ton of annoying problems. You have to meet it where it's at (which is not a great place) to enjoy it, so beware before buying. Some issues off the top of my head:

* There's a lot of things you need to know that the game doesn't communicate well. Some light googling here and there is necessary to make sure that you haven't missed a whole entire party member, for example.

* Some spells just don't seem to work? For example hypnotism or banishment (which sounds powerful until you try to use it), I never got them to do anything at all.

* In turn based, sometimes you will try to cast a spell in battle and your character moves into position, stops short of casting the spell and you just lose your turn.

* I managed to break a main story quest. There's a major boss that I insta killed by using a clever combination of abilities, which felt very good, but then I found out that there's supposed to be a custcene when he gets to low health and I skipped that. I noticed because the journal said that a certain character had betrayed me and left my party, and I was looking at him right there. I reset to a previous save and I have no idea what would have happened otherwise. In a complex RPG such as this one, it feels especially frustrating to be punished for trying an alternative solution.

* Kingdom management events come with an expiration date, and often you will get swamped with many problems at the same time. You're expected to prioritize, but then some events will expire one month before their stated date.

* The endgame is an absolute slog. I don't know how they thought it was a good idea to spam so many identical and extremely annoying combat encounters. It feels like padding in a game you have already sunk 100+ hours into. You will find a lot of comments online of people who threw their hands up and lowered the difficulty in the very last dungeons because they just couldn't be bothered.

I want to make it clear that there is an excellent game with great characters, combat, and systems hiding underneath all this, but be prepared to exercise a lot of patience.

Kingmaker started Owlcat down their contemporary artistic vision of building love letters to a bygone era of table top role-playing games. The history of Pathfinder is central to many of the first backers love of the game. 

The 3.5/4e schism brought Pathfinder; envisioned as the 'capital R' Role-players alternative to the 'lowercase r' roll-players who followed Wizards to 4e. Pathfinder's crunch was envisioned to allow a high level of class customizability compared to what players had come to expect from the typical DnD class system, mainly through feats. In this way to players with the same class would be distinct.

The differences in the mediums of tabletop and CRPG present unique boons and challenges for the pathfinder system

At the table top, to achieve this high simulation style of play, players could be dealing with large and time consuming equations often which slows gameplays (and has led to the current eco system of rules lite ttrpgs we see today).
The crunch heavy rpg that translates well to a CRPG where your machine can handle the math for you and results are quick and don’t get in the way of the action

However, playing your character (let alone the 5 other companions) requires a level of mechanical knowledge, of a now out of date RPG system, that cant be expected of the modern player. Pathfinder 1e/3.5 is a great but flawed product and a great example of a time where high simulation was important to ttrpgs. It's rules are vast and complex and require a strong knowledge of the keywords the game uses and how the interact. Which at the table can be learned through the shared game experience at the table. On your own at a computer, it may requires some research, or trial and error. This is Owlcats first game, and they have made refinements to their latest titles, but Kingmaker in particular is a little light on tutorials for such a complex rpg system. 

One would benefit from having the Pathfinder 1e core rule book while playing, which shouldn’t be required to play, luckily the 3.5SRD is open licence and free online. Skiming the core rules, your class mechanics, and party class mechanics will help reduce the learning curve.

If you love CRPGs and want to experience one of the best fantasy settings, pathfinder rewards those who take the time to learn. The realms of Golarian are vast and rich and offer something to all roleplayers. Fans of heavy deep lore will be well rewarded for their investments. Deep roleplayers who want to take a character concept a really build it, not just flavour it, will spend hours finetuning builds. The River Kingdoms may seem to be a generic fantasy setting, but scratch the surface and you'll see why you shouldn't judge a book by it's cover.

I started Pathfinder: Kingmaker thinking I’d be the noble ruler of a proud realm.
Ten hours later, I was knee-deep in tax reports, kingdom unrest, and three missing companions because I forgot to rest for five days.
Every decision feels important until you realize the real enemy isn’t trolls or undead — it’s the RNG dice roll that keeps ruining your diplomacy.
The combat is brutal, the dialogue is endless, and the loading screens give you time to reflect on your poor life choices.
But somehow… it’s brilliant. The story sucks you in, the companions are lovable disasters, and every victory feels earned — mostly because you survived the UI.
I wanted to be a ruler, but ended up a sleep-deprived peasant with a crown.

One of the few RPGs that veers away from the typical 'chosen one/save the world' storyline. Instead, Kingmaker places you at the head of a group of adventurers who attempt to establish a barony in an unclaimed land. 

The companions in this game are in my opinion its standout feature. Almost all of them are well written and a joy to travel with and fight alongside. The companion stories are all well done and some are even directly tied to the main quest which makes them feel like an integral part of the story and not just your lackeys. All in all, this gives the game a very 'Fellowship of the Ring' vibe which I absolutely loved. 

The main story itself is excellent, though it is a slow-burn. At the start the stakes are relatively low - which again is rare for RPGs. As you go along, the narrative slowly begins to unravel and the stakes ramp up. It all culminates in a satisfying conclusion which makes you feel like the choices you made along the way mattered. 

The only things holding it back is the somewhat clunky Pathfinder 1E system and some questionable encounter/dungeon design. Essentially, if you're not familiar with the system, you will struggle with even the tutorial encounters. Either play on a lower difficulty until you find your footing or refer to a guide online. The game also has some performance issues in some areas/battles - even though I play on a decent rig, I still got major frame drops in some sections.  

Then there's the Kingdom Management section of the game which is quite polarising. If you lose in this management sim, your campaign will end! Thankfully, you can circumvent this by lowering the Kingdom Management difficulty to the lowest setting, so it's not that big of an issue. Alternatively, you can skip the sim entirely by putting it on Auto mode. Personally, I wouldn't recommend this as you lose out on a lot of flavour and character interactions that are exclusive to this mode.

Still, the pros far outweigh the cons overall. Kingmaker is simply one of the best role-playing experiences to come out in recent times!

Of all the Owlcat games, this is the hardest to get through. 

It was and still is incredibly ambitious and borderline demented, but this ambition comes with drawbacks, many of which they only started to remedy in their more recent titles (WotR and Rogue Trader). It is incredibly long, to the point where the endgame is more of a marathon than a glorious climax. This marathon sadly extends to the gameplay as endless waves of trash fights, for which you still have to sort of min-max and buff up tho (thanks PF 1e), simply get boring and tedious after a while. 

Choices and consequences also suffer from the game lenght. Without more specialised RP options and world consequences, any alignment path besides Chaotic good will feel severely out of place and weird. The Mythic system in WotR did wonders to remedy this, but once again this is an example of a lesson learned from a non-functional aspect of Kingmaker. 

The endings are also severely undercooked and do not synergise between eachother, it is so bad I wouldve prefered a "You win" screen to what I got. This is a problem in all 3 Owlcat CRPGs to date, and I cannot pinpoint why it keeps happening. Fallout New Vegas did good and cohesive ending slides back in 2010, you dont have to re-invent the wheel here. 

So after all this, why the thumbs up? Well for one, as a product of its time, it is amazing and the sheer gravitas of this game being the springboard from which Owlcat began their rise into the CRPG game market is incredible. Taking something so niche, executing it so incredibly, painstakingly accurate that it actually becomes a detriment and still create a fun and engaging product is nothing short of awesome. 

The build variety is great (Although somewhat limited if one wants to play on anything higher than Normal), the scope of adventuring around and managing a kingdom at the same time feel good (IF IT WAS SHORTER) and some character arcs are legitimately cool, you can become attached to these people as well as your kingdom as a whole and Owlcat's writing definitely proved itself in their very first entry already. 

Sadly,  less than 10 % of the playerbase has the "you win" Achievement. Less than 10 % actually finished the game. This is somewhat expected, considering the niche nature of the game and it many non accessible aspects, but its still sad. In my opinion, no matter how niche, a game shouldn't be not finished by a large majority of players and I blame the lenght above anything. You can play the same Pen & paper campaign for many years, but this lenght, this maturing of story which comes naturally in IRL Roleplaying, cannot be translated to a videogame. 

I bet most people had fun for their first 30, 35 or even 40 hours, but just didn't have it in them to run the final 100 miles. In hindsight they didn't miss much, truely, but this problem with Owlcat games dragging on and simply not holding attention long enough started here with their very first release. WotR upped the completion rate to almost 12 % while rogue trader sits at roughly 17 %. They are slowly catching up the Behemoth of BG 3 with its almost 22 % completion rate, but neither has figured out a way to make most people see these long adventures through. 

TLDR: Digressions aside, Kingmaker is fun, but tedious. It is detailed but often sloppy. It is grand but often confusing. In the end only the biggest of CRPG fans will see the adventure through, but I like to see the game more as the beginning of a bigger adventure; the adventure of Owlcat games and their struggle to bring CRPGs and niche PnP games solidly into the mainstream. As an "Act 1" of this adventure, Kingmaker is well worth a recommendation.

The game adapts the tabletop Pathfinder ruleset into a lengthy CRPG about exploration and political leadership. You begin as an adventurer and progress toward ruling a growing kingdom. The narrative mixes dungeon crawling with regional management.

Character creation is dense. Classes, archetypes, feats, and spell lists allow deep build paths. New players may feel overwhelmed. Veterans can refine party roles for late-game encounters. Progression rewards system knowledge.

Combat is real-time-with-pause. Positioning, crowd control, and buff sequences influence outcomes. Enemy resistances and saving throws matter. High difficulty punishes unprepared parties. Timing and spell synergy carry weight.

Kingdom management adds a strategic layer. You assign advisors, handle crises, and develop regions. Poor management can cause collapse. The system adds consequence but can feel punishing. Events occur on strict timers.

The Enhanced Plus Edition improves stability, balance, and interface clarity. Loading times are shorter. Visual readability is better. Navigation through inventories and spell books shows less friction.

Audio is effective. Ambient tracks support wilderness zones. Voice acting highlights major conversations. Spell effects and creature sounds provide useful cues. Overall sound design is functional.

The game suits players who enjoy long CRPG campaigns that reward planning. Complexity is high but yields satisfaction. Kingdom management introduces stress but enhances immersion. Strong value for fans of tactical party building.

I tried to start a few times and always ended up finding something more interesting to do instead. Between attempts, I did a bunch of research, and I discovered that the game, while interesting, has a huge number of sharp corners that can result in an extremely unpleasant experience.

One dungeon at the end of the campaign in particular, The House on the Edge of Time, or something like that, is infamous for having many players drop their campaigns in it.

For such a massive game, the prospect of encountering these things is very discouraging. Especially since i'm sure a good portion of my time here would simply be padding.

Besides that, the very easy possibility of creating useless builds if you don't have a deep understanding of the system (because balancing a video game with this amount of variables is practically impossible) or being overwhelmed by a kingdom management system that even the game's most die-hard fans seem to hate tells me the game doesn't seem worth the time.

Still, with the little I've played, I've been able to recognize qualities that some players might appreciate, such as a high level of customization and role-playing opportunities (as long as it's within the game's simplistic tone), and the nearly inexhaustible replayability these factors offer.

The presentation in almost every way is excellent for a mid-budget game in this genre.

And for better or worse, at least they do a good job of covering the game with information everywhere, so as long as you have the patience for a tutorial format that requires a lot of effort and probably isn't all that worthwhile, it should work because the information will at least be there, in ample detail, even if not intuitively.

The writing, however, seems quite poor. Long paragraphs, full of redundant prose. No objectivity whatsoever. Flowery, but lacking eloquence or genuine emotion to color the text and simultaneously function as a conversation.

It doesn't take long, and right in the prologue, you'll see examples of diplomacy checks where the logic and arguments presented make no sense, and certain characters will accept very stupid and forced opposing arguments simply because you failed the checks.

People with completely nonsensical motivations who seem to have stepped out of a cartoon for very young children.

The characters seem like parodies straight out of the rulebooks.

The feeling I got was that a game designed to fit a niche of 10-year-olds who have a PhD.

Still, you might be one of those legendary kids, or you might be more tolerant of the writing than I am, and actually get to the meat of the story and find something interesting there, or you might simply enjoy the gameplay for its gargantuan complexity. So, since I didn't make it all the way to the end, I'll give it a thumbs up. Because I actually didn't find anything major wrong with the game so far, though I've resigned myself to not trying to play it again.

It seems like an ambitious project that could well benefit from being cut in half and having the rules and options streamlined to make it easier to join in on the fun, if it even exists.

The general recommendations I found were to ignore more than half of the content, which is always a bad sign.

After a long period of time when I basically only played JRPG's I decided that I needed a change of pace and, since it had been a long time since I'd played any isometric CRPG's I went back to play some of the gems I'd missed over the years. After playing Divinity: Original Sin 1 & 2, Pillars of Eternity and Baldur's Gate 3, I decided to give this one a try.

I'm happy to say I'm having fun with it and that it kind of feels like a middle point between Divinity and Baldur's Gate 3, since it does use the Pathfinder rules, that are based on the D&D open license, but it understandably lacks the high-end cutscenes and visual presentation of the newer game. It's not quite as complex as what Larian does, since their games are really detailed and give you a lot of freedom, but it doesn't feel as outdated and clunky as Pillars of Eternity did, despite the fact that Pillars of Eternity literally came out a year after the original Divinity: Original Sin but still manages to feel like a much older game.

Kingmaker is fun and feels like a newer version of the old Baldur's Gate games, but it does have its flaws, such as the annoying mechanics that have to do with resting and camping when your characters get tired, which happens all the time because the game is literally designed to make you travel from point A to point whatever a ton of times, and it has a glaring flaw with random encounters during those travels because you run the risk of stupid crap like running into a random battle with, say, a dozen greater elementals despite the fact that you're like level 5 and there's zero reason why from a story standpoint so many powerful monsters would be randomly roaming around together in some backwater road, so that if you run into that stupid encounter you're dead no matter what you do and you can't run away easily and you'll lose whatever progress you'd made since your last save. That's just B.S. and a terrible design choice that I'm amazed hasn't been fixed by a patch after so many years and full on gigantic sequel.

Other than that, I'm digging slowly building up my barony/kingdom in parallel of the usual adventuring, since the former usually involves making story-based decisions and managing resources, and the latter is the more traditional gameplay loop where you go out dungeon crawling and fighting monsters or bad guys. I also like that your companions can disagree with you and each other, and sometimes even choices that seem like the "correct" one from the traditional "good guy" standpoint might elicit an unexpected response from a companion that has some unique view regarding that specific issue regardless of what you'd expect from their alignment.

Edit: After 20+ hours and in the middle of Act 3 I screwed up because I was too busy running my kingdom and chasing timed companion quests and so on, and I realized I had 16 in-game hours to get to the location of a main quest or the kingdom would be destroyed, which triggers an automatic and unavoidable game over. Thing is, I was all the way to the other side of the map and it was impossible to make it in time so it was game over and there was nothing to be done about it except go back to a save file that has so old that I might as well start over again. I get it, it's on me, but it's still annoying and made me drop the game until I feel like trying again.

Edit 2: After literally going off to play the entirety of the sequel Wrath of the Righteous and its DLC's, so that I got over my annoyance at my previous screw-up playing this game, I decided to start over again from scratch and make a new character taking advantage of all I learned during my first failed playthrough and my WotR playthrough and I have to say that I really enjoyed the experience. 

I was actually surprised that I kept running into stuff I didn't encounter the first time around, including many more quests, a couple of recruitable companions I didn't meet the first time, and locations/items my characters didn't find due to having lower/different Perception scores. So, in sum, except for a few bugs and clunky mechanics having to do with traveling from place to place or the way the game uses "real" time to trigger events, I honestly think this is a really good game and I appreciate that the sequel has a very different story and each of the two games felt distinctly their own thing, despite being loosely connected by virtue of the setting and some NPC's you meet in both games. I hope they make a third one, and I'll play the WH40K games made by the same studio in the meantime.

Kingmaker started Owlcat down their contemporary artistic vision of building love letters to a bygone era of table top role-playing games. The history of Pathfinder is central to many of the first backers love of the game. 

The 3.5/4e schism brought Pathfinder; envisioned as the 'capital R' Role-players alternative to the 'lowercase r' roll-players who followed Wizards to 4e. Pathfinder's crunch was envisioned to allow a high level of class customizability compared to what players had come to expect from the typical DnD class system, mainly through feats. In this way to players with the same class would be distinct.

The differences in the mediums of tabletop and CRPG present unique boons and challenges for the pathfinder system

At the table top, to achieve this high simulation style of play, players could be dealing with large and time consuming equations often which slows gameplays (and has led to the current eco system of rules lite ttrpgs we see today).
The crunch heavy rpg that translates well to a CRPG where your machine can handle the math for you and results are quick and don’t get in the way of the action

However, playing your character (let alone the 5 other companions) requires a level of mechanical knowledge, of a now out of date RPG system, that cant be expected of the modern player. Pathfinder 1e/3.5 is a great but flawed product and a great example of a time where high simulation was important to ttrpgs. It's rules are vast and complex and require a strong knowledge of the keywords the game uses and how the interact. Which at the table can be learned through the shared game experience at the table. On your own at a computer, it may requires some research, or trial and error. This is Owlcats first game, and they have made refinements to their latest titles, but Kingmaker in particular is a little light on tutorials for such a complex rpg system.

[h2]Review after 3 Hours: Deep Pathfinder System, Annoying Prologue & Characters[/h2]
I really wanted to like this game. It clearly offers a deep and faithful implementation of the Pathfinder ruleset - all the feats, skills, spells, and checks are there, and the interface for reviewing character builds and progression is nicely done.

What completely turned me off, though, was the prologue and its characters. The game forces on you an obnoxious female Bard companion who insists on chronicling your adventures because “you’re destined to be a hero.” That alone was grating, but what really broke it for me was discovering that the [i]journal interface[/i] is written entirely from the Bard’s perspective  meaning this irritating character is tied directly to the game’s core UI.  I don’t know if that changes later, but it was enough to stop me right there.

The setup also leans hard on clichés,  a sweaty, bloodthirsty female barbarian, a snarky evil sorcerer you have to tolerate for no reason, and the usual “heroes summoned to a mansion for a shared quest” trope. It all felt predictable, and the so-called twist in the prologue didn’t help.

That said, there’s no denying the game looks good for its genre and has a lot of mechanical depth. Fans of the Pathfinder ruleset will probably enjoy it. But for me, the writing, tone, and character presentation in the early game were just too off-putting.

Pathfinder: Kingmaker is an RPG that is a lot of fun at the beginning, but unfortunately quickly becomes redundant. In the game, the kingdom is constantly plagued by threats such as pandemics, wars with neighbours and barbarians. Although the story is okay at the beginning, it eventually becomes uninteresting due to the unreasonably long playing time. What we have here is a story for perhaps 30 to 35 hours stretched to almost 80 hours, according to HLTB.

Another point of criticism is the unnecessarily difficult battles in the later stages of the game. Instead of the enemies becoming stronger and more powerful, you are simply bombarded with an excess of 20 to 30 enemies. This not only affects the game performance, but also the enjoyment of the game.

One annoying aspect is that potential companions can be missed. As these companions are needed for kingdom management, this leads to problems. An example is a companion who is found in an uninteresting location during a single specific main quest. It is possible to spend the entire game without a chamberlain, causing the kingdom to fail and the game to be lost. One could argue that you should simply explore more, but this leads to the next point of criticism.

All quests have an invisible time limit, which reduces the enjoyment of the game. Although it is realistic that NPCs do not stay in one place indefinitely, this gives the player little freedom. What if you want to pursue the main quest before doing the companions' side quests? What if you want to explore the map, but time passes and you run the risk of losing the game? What if you just want to spend a few months in the game managing the kingdom?

The questlog often does not give you enough information. In the majority of the quests you will find yourself wandering all over the world map hoping to finally find the place you are supposed to go. I think it's pretty obvious that this, along with the time limit, is pretty bad design.

Despite these points of criticism, there are also aspects worthy of praise. The level of difficulty can be customised very nicely so that both pros and newcomers can have fun with the game. In addition, kingdom management can be minimised by only taking on the most necessary tasks. The lore of Pathfinder is also explained quite well, so that even players who have never come into contact with Pathfinder before are not completely lost.

It's fun until you realize that at the end of the day this is a dice rolling simulator, and since there's no actual GM to work with the player gameplay boils down to "Roll a 20? You win. Roll a 1? You Lose, Skill Issue." The player has very little actual agency beyond character creation, and the storyline is not good enough to justify spending hours at a time rolling a 20-sided die over and over again hoping "just roll high bro 4head".

Having bounced off the bitterly disappointing Kingmaker PF2E module (also we got owned because we're bad), I thought I'd give Kingmaker another try. I thought having the Kingdom turns be automatable and skipping the group consensus element that the tabletop module forces on you would be nice, and it is, but as this isn't a review of the tabletop game I can only say it's still a boring and disappointing system regardless. The Kingdom system drives a lot of the plot but there is little tangible incentive to actually engage with it beyond "you have to", so it very quickly becomes a chore that keeps you from the meat of the game, the adventuring. It could have done with either being much more abstract, or much more granular, but the system would require a complete ground up rework to be engaging to me.

The combat itself is built on a strong basis, with the Pathfinder First Edition system being a solid tabletop system. The NPC companions are pretty unlikeable (save for Linzi, who grew on me) and unmemorable, the second most interesting being Valerie who happens to be probably the weakest class in the entire system and certainly of the starting companions. You severely lack options for Cleric or INT caster archetypes that are only somewhat fixed when you get access to a Sorceror, or the Arcane Trickster you can lean more into the magic side with. Nobody is a conventional, well-rounded base class by default, and while you can retrain them  more or less as you please it's irritating getting to grips with a roster full of quirky subclasses and learning what they can do when I'd really rather just have the NPC companions be simple archetypes while my own character can grow as desired. There are automation options, but these just further divorce you from the decision making process. 

Luckily, the game is not all that hard, so you don't really need to care about the above composition issues that much, but rather repetitive to the point of boring. Slogging through overly large zones separated by long stretches of overland travel, which don't really run into each other as much as feel like separate instances is just not enjoyable, before you get into the tedium of progressing the kingdom to even access the content. It feels very much like the game is padded out to keep you from noticing how thin it is outside of the core content, which is still not even all that good. I didn't feel motivated to finish the game because I just got bored, which is honestly pretty rare for me, and didn't even catch up to the part in the Tabletop we TPKed at, which was my motivation to play the game in the first place.

If you have played every other CRPG and are dying for a new one then by all means play it, but I would strongly recommend just picking up WOTR instead, which has far fewer of the downsides. To sum it up, it just feels like Kingmaker doesn't respect your time - just adding mounts could've fixed about a quarter of what's wrong with the game. At least it's pretty cheap and regularly goes on sale at 80% off.

I have mostly negative takeways from Kingmaker, most have to do with the RTwP combat system, encounter design and balancing, as well as stability issues. The few things it does get right are not enough to make up for all the dubious design choices and other shortcomings.

Positives:

• The writing starts off weird, like a Tumblr user's fanfic with characters using silly terms like "freaking", "kick butts" etc. Fortunately it is an anomaly that is mostly contained to the prologue, the quality shifts for the better after that and stays consistent throughout.
• Nice art direction on the monsters and some good variety there too, I also like the environments.
• The soundtrack is pretty nice.

Mixed:

• Most of the quests are fetch quests, the main story is where the quality content is at but you won't be doing that for 150h. I was very disappointed with the way most of the Companions' arcs ended, they build up throughout the game towards what you'd expect to be a satisfying climax only to end on a whiff. Also I really did not appreciate the shoehorned way they handle Linzi - just a PSA: if you, like me, have Linzi as your party's main support & lockpicker/ disarmer, do yourself a favor and remove all her gear before entering the final dungeon.
• Speaking of companions, they are written fine, I enjoyed them for the most part. they aren't up there with the best from Dragon Age (ie. 1 & 2), Mass Effect, DOS2 and not even close to BG3 companions but they are good enough.

Negatives:

• RTwP. This abomination of a combat system single-handedly kills off most games in the cRPG genre, it is a relic of gaming much like fixed camera angles and tank controls are and it should be left alone as such. To actually make it work takes a lot of effort and even then it is just better to either have full realtime combat or full turn-based.
• Atrocious encounter design and wildly inconsistent general balancing, dubious design choices. Enemy spam, constant interruptions while you travel the map. Random one shots can happen wherever and whenever even on lower difficulties. Enemies not only have access to but also spam CCs that last for like 30+ seconds (hello Wild Gaze.) "Permanent" debuff types that can be removed only by Resting, such as losing levels and attributes/ stats. If you want to clear the hard content, you read a guide on how to min-max and then spend a good 5 minutes stacking like 50 buffs before every tough fight.
• Time limits and not just on side quests but main quests too, that give you a Game Over if ignored. I legitimately cannot think of any game that has time limits and was praised for it, Kingmaker is most certainly not an exception to that.
• Kingdom management, this is almost universally disliked from what I've seen and read, even the devs themselves added options to skip it completely, that's how bad it is. Just padding to inflate playtime, not to mention that mishandling it can brick your campaign if you don't save often because of the way in which it interacts with time limits.
• UI: imo half of the mastery in making cRPGs/ Strategy games is in how clean and readable the UI is, if your game has convoluted mechanics but the UI is good, it creates a pleasant and rewarding learning environment for the player. When the UI looks and feels sloppy it does the opposite, case in point Kingmaker. And don't get me started on the lack of QoLs, I feel like I'm walking away from the game with a strained wrist from all the clicking due to inventory management.
• So many bugs and glitches, poor overall stability. For starters, the game minimizes if you alt-tab or click on a 2nd monitor when you have it on "Borderless Windowed" - that kind of defeats one of the primary purposes of that setting I think. Random total slow-mos on your party that happen very frequently, which you fix with Pause/ Unpause. Characters get stuck on invisible walls, especially when combat is triggered. Death's Door can trigger randomly on area traversal, and sometimes it doesn't get healed even when resting in safe areas. New items and existing ones get sorted completely randomly and erratically in your inventory, skipping entire empty columns or even pages for some reason - if you do inventory management to fix it, they'll auto-sort next time you interact with merchants or your storage anyway. Achievements don't unlock way too often and it really sucks when it happens to quests that span the entire game eg. Magic Prison. I was very thorough in my playthrough, so thorough that after checking every unlock condition I should've had 3/4 of the total achievements yet I finished with only 1/4 unlocked. If the game loses focus often (alt-tab, clicking on second monitor) it messes up either your Storage or Memory, it creates system-wide slowdowns and micro-freezes that don't go away even if you turn it off, what fixes it is signing out of Windows or a full restart.

Even with all the cheesy nonsense this game overwhelms you with I was very close to walking away from it having had an okay experience because it does have some charm to it, however the final area just dialed the nonsense up to eleven with the enemy and CC spam, frustratingly obtuse area and puzzle design as well as cheesy encounters. Literally every negative aspect that I could tolerate before got compounded to 3-5h of non-stop frustration that had me breathing a sigh of relief when it was all over. I just can't recommend Kingmaker for anyone but the biggest cRPG/ DnD addicts with how flawed of an experience it is. Go play Divinity or Baldur's Gate instead.

This game is imminently and interminably frustrating. I am not a Pathfinder player, but I have experience with the 3.5 Dungeons and Dragons rule-set that it was based on. I can note a few improvements, but the statement that pathfinder "fixed" the problems with D&D is, in my opinion, erroneous. With that background out of the way, I'll start with the biggest issue. The kingdom management system, frankly, just isn't very good. If the purpose of it was to make you feel like you have important choices to make in the development of your barony (and later on, your kingdom), then I consider it a failure. The constant events that crop up far too frequently make it taxing to attempt building up your lands, especially in the early and middle chapters of the game, and what's worse is that the main story is all timed. You can switch the kingdom system to automatic, and I highly recommend doing so, but it is a major component of the game, and it should not be so tempting to turn it off unless you are simply uninterested in that type of game-play. I did like the town building, though, so there's that.

Returning to the timed story-lines, that is another major issue with the game as a whole. Not the mere presence of a time-based element, which I can find some enjoyment in (as you can note by my playtime with various entries in the Atelier series), but the obtuse implementation and the hidden fail-states are grating and unnecessary. There are several quests that clearly show how long you have to finish them, primarily those on the main story portions, but there are others that fail upon reaching undeclared moments in the story or after unknown amounts of time. If all quests were time-sensitive, at least you could prioritize and decide which quests are worth your time, and which you're willing to fail, or even plan out your exploration and adventuring efficiently so you can get them all done. But without outside knowledge, there's no way of knowing which quests will fail after a certain amount of time and which can wait until you have a spare few days.

Beyond that, this game has many bugs, unintuitive user interface, and a baffling relationship with the D&D alignment system. It is extremely bizarre to me, for instance, that a pair of lovers who care deeply about each other would just shrug off one of them being good and one of them being evil. I don't see how any healthy relationship could survive when one of the things they disagree on is "murder is wrong".

That being said, the art and music are lovely and the characters come to life in the game's stronger moments. I don't buy the level of camaraderie they supposedly share with each other by the end (it would make more sense to me that most of them simply tolerate one another due to their relationship to the player character), but they are fully realized in their own moments, and in the conversations you share with them. The story has many archetypal beats and it feels very aimless during its middle portions. The reveal of how all these disparate events are related probably could have been dropped earlier for a stronger narrative, I think. But overall, it is a story of reclaiming what is lost, and banding together even when it doesn't make sense. And there are many moments where you really feel your choices playing out throughout the land and over the years, in particular a gift you receive early on in the game comes in handy at a very late chapter of the story, which made for a great moment in my play-through.

Overall, I can only really recommend this gamer to people who are fans of the Pathfinder role-playing system. But for everyone else, I say avoid this absolute time vampire!

Pathfinder: Kingmaker is an RPG that is a lot of fun at the beginning, but unfortunately quickly becomes redundant. In the game, the kingdom is constantly plagued by threats such as pandemics, wars with neighbours and barbarians. Although the story is okay at the beginning, it eventually becomes uninteresting due to the unreasonably long playing time. What we have here is a story for perhaps 30 to 35 hours stretched to almost 80 hours, according to HLTB.

Another point of criticism is the unnecessarily difficult battles in the later stages of the game. Instead of the enemies becoming stronger and more powerful, you are simply bombarded with an excess of 20 to 30 enemies. This not only affects the game performance, but also the enjoyment of the game.

One annoying aspect is that potential companions can be missed. As these companions are needed for kingdom management, this leads to problems. An example is a companion who is found in an uninteresting location during a single specific main quest. It is possible to spend the entire game without a chamberlain, causing the kingdom to fail and the game to be lost. One could argue that you should simply explore more, but this leads to the next point of criticism.

All quests have an invisible time limit, which reduces the enjoyment of the game. Although it is realistic that NPCs do not stay in one place indefinitely, this gives the player little freedom. What if you want to pursue the main quest before doing the companions' side quests? What if you want to explore the map, but time passes and you run the risk of losing the game? What if you just want to spend a few months in the game managing the kingdom?

The questlog often does not give you enough information. In the majority of the quests you will find yourself wandering all over the world map hoping to finally find the place you are supposed to go. I think it's pretty obvious that this, along with the time limit, is pretty bad design.

Despite these points of criticism, there are also aspects worthy of praise. The level of difficulty can be customised very nicely so that both pros and newcomers can have fun with the game. In addition, kingdom management can be minimised by only taking on the most necessary tasks. The lore of Pathfinder is also explained quite well, so that even players who have never come into contact with Pathfinder before are not completely lost.

It's fun until you realize that at the end of the day this is a dice rolling simulator, and since there's no actual GM to work with the player gameplay boils down to "Roll a 20? You win. Roll a 1? You Lose, Skill Issue." The player has very little actual agency beyond character creation, and the storyline is not good enough to justify spending hours at a time rolling a 20-sided die over and over again hoping "just roll high bro 4head".

Having bounced off the bitterly disappointing Kingmaker PF2E module (also we got owned because we're bad), I thought I'd give Kingmaker another try. I thought having the Kingdom turns be automatable and skipping the group consensus element that the tabletop module forces on you would be nice, and it is, but as this isn't a review of the tabletop game I can only say it's still a boring and disappointing system regardless. The Kingdom system drives a lot of the plot but there is little tangible incentive to actually engage with it beyond "you have to", so it very quickly becomes a chore that keeps you from the meat of the game, the adventuring. It could have done with either being much more abstract, or much more granular, but the system would require a complete ground up rework to be engaging to me.

The combat itself is built on a strong basis, with the Pathfinder First Edition system being a solid tabletop system. The NPC companions are pretty unlikeable (save for Linzi, who grew on me) and unmemorable, the second most interesting being Valerie who happens to be probably the weakest class in the entire system and certainly of the starting companions. You severely lack options for Cleric or INT caster archetypes that are only somewhat fixed when you get access to a Sorceror, or the Arcane Trickster you can lean more into the magic side with. Nobody is a conventional, well-rounded base class by default, and while you can retrain them  more or less as you please it's irritating getting to grips with a roster full of quirky subclasses and learning what they can do when I'd really rather just have the NPC companions be simple archetypes while my own character can grow as desired. There are automation options, but these just further divorce you from the decision making process. 

Luckily, the game is not all that hard, so you don't really need to care about the above composition issues that much, but rather repetitive to the point of boring. Slogging through overly large zones separated by long stretches of overland travel, which don't really run into each other as much as feel like separate instances is just not enjoyable, before you get into the tedium of progressing the kingdom to even access the content. It feels very much like the game is padded out to keep you from noticing how thin it is outside of the core content, which is still not even all that good. I didn't feel motivated to finish the game because I just got bored, which is honestly pretty rare for me, and didn't even catch up to the part in the Tabletop we TPKed at, which was my motivation to play the game in the first place.

If you have played every other CRPG and are dying for a new one then by all means play it, but I would strongly recommend just picking up WOTR instead, which has far fewer of the downsides. To sum it up, it just feels like Kingmaker doesn't respect your time - just adding mounts could've fixed about a quarter of what's wrong with the game. At least it's pretty cheap and regularly goes on sale at 80% off.

I have mostly negative takeways from Kingmaker, most have to do with the RTwP combat system, encounter design and balancing, as well as stability issues. The few things it does get right are not enough to make up for all the dubious design choices and other shortcomings.

Positives:

• The writing starts off weird, like a Tumblr user's fanfic with characters using silly terms like "freaking", "kick butts" etc. Fortunately it is an anomaly that is mostly contained to the prologue, the quality shifts for the better after that and stays consistent throughout.
• Nice art direction on the monsters and some good variety there too, I also like the environments.
• The soundtrack is pretty nice.

Mixed:

• Most of the quests are fetch quests, the main story is where the quality content is at but you won't be doing that for 150h. I was very disappointed with the way most of the Companions' arcs ended, they build up throughout the game towards what you'd expect to be a satisfying climax only to end on a whiff. Also I really did not appreciate the shoehorned way they handle Linzi - just a PSA: if you, like me, have Linzi as your party's main support & lockpicker/ disarmer, do yourself a favor and remove all her gear before entering the final dungeon.
• Speaking of companions, they are written fine, I enjoyed them for the most part. they aren't up there with the best from Dragon Age (ie. 1 & 2), Mass Effect, DOS2 and not even close to BG3 companions but they are good enough.

Negatives:

• RTwP. This abomination of a combat system single-handedly kills off most games in the cRPG genre, it is a relic of gaming much like fixed camera angles and tank controls are and it should be left alone as such. To actually make it work takes a lot of effort and even then it is just better to either have full realtime combat or full turn-based.
• Atrocious encounter design and wildly inconsistent general balancing, dubious design choices. Enemy spam, constant interruptions while you travel the map. Random one shots can happen wherever and whenever even on lower difficulties. Enemies not only have access to but also spam CCs that last for like 30+ seconds (hello Wild Gaze.) "Permanent" debuff types that can be removed only by Resting, such as losing levels and attributes/ stats. If you want to clear the hard content, you read a guide on how to min-max and then spend a good 5 minutes stacking like 50 buffs before every tough fight.
• Time limits and not just on side quests but main quests too, that give you a Game Over if ignored. I legitimately cannot think of any game that has time limits and was praised for it, Kingmaker is most certainly not an exception to that.
• Kingdom management, this is almost universally disliked from what I've seen and read, even the devs themselves added options to skip it completely, that's how bad it is. Just padding to inflate playtime, not to mention that mishandling it can brick your campaign if you don't save often because of the way in which it interacts with time limits.
• UI: imo half of the mastery in making cRPGs/ Strategy games is in how clean and readable the UI is, if your game has convoluted mechanics but the UI is good, it creates a pleasant and rewarding learning environment for the player. When the UI looks and feels sloppy it does the opposite, case in point Kingmaker. And don't get me started on the lack of QoLs, I feel like I'm walking away from the game with a strained wrist from all the clicking due to inventory management.
• So many bugs and glitches, poor overall stability. For starters, the game minimizes if you alt-tab or click on a 2nd monitor when you have it on "Borderless Windowed" - that kind of defeats one of the primary purposes of that setting I think. Random total slow-mos on your party that happen very frequently, which you fix with Pause/ Unpause. Characters get stuck on invisible walls, especially when combat is triggered. Death's Door can trigger randomly on area traversal, and sometimes it doesn't get healed even when resting in safe areas. New items and existing ones get sorted completely randomly and erratically in your inventory, skipping entire empty columns or even pages for some reason - if you do inventory management to fix it, they'll auto-sort next time you interact with merchants or your storage anyway. Achievements don't unlock way too often and it really sucks when it happens to quests that span the entire game eg. Magic Prison. I was very thorough in my playthrough, so thorough that after checking every unlock condition I should've had 3/4 of the total achievements yet I finished with only 1/4 unlocked. If the game loses focus often (alt-tab, clicking on second monitor) it messes up either your Storage or Memory, it creates system-wide slowdowns and micro-freezes that don't go away even if you turn it off, what fixes it is signing out of Windows or a full restart.

Even with all the cheesy nonsense this game overwhelms you with I was very close to walking away from it having had an okay experience because it does have some charm to it, however the final area just dialed the nonsense up to eleven with the enemy and CC spam, frustratingly obtuse area and puzzle design as well as cheesy encounters. Literally every negative aspect that I could tolerate before got compounded to 3-5h of non-stop frustration that had me breathing a sigh of relief when it was all over. I just can't recommend Kingmaker for anyone but the biggest cRPG/ DnD addicts with how flawed of an experience it is. Go play Divinity or Baldur's Gate instead.

This game is imminently and interminably frustrating. I am not a Pathfinder player, but I have experience with the 3.5 Dungeons and Dragons rule-set that it was based on. I can note a few improvements, but the statement that pathfinder "fixed" the problems with D&D is, in my opinion, erroneous. With that background out of the way, I'll start with the biggest issue. The kingdom management system, frankly, just isn't very good. If the purpose of it was to make you feel like you have important choices to make in the development of your barony (and later on, your kingdom), then I consider it a failure. The constant events that crop up far too frequently make it taxing to attempt building up your lands, especially in the early and middle chapters of the game, and what's worse is that the main story is all timed. You can switch the kingdom system to automatic, and I highly recommend doing so, but it is a major component of the game, and it should not be so tempting to turn it off unless you are simply uninterested in that type of game-play. I did like the town building, though, so there's that.

Returning to the timed story-lines, that is another major issue with the game as a whole. Not the mere presence of a time-based element, which I can find some enjoyment in (as you can note by my playtime with various entries in the Atelier series), but the obtuse implementation and the hidden fail-states are grating and unnecessary. There are several quests that clearly show how long you have to finish them, primarily those on the main story portions, but there are others that fail upon reaching undeclared moments in the story or after unknown amounts of time. If all quests were time-sensitive, at least you could prioritize and decide which quests are worth your time, and which you're willing to fail, or even plan out your exploration and adventuring efficiently so you can get them all done. But without outside knowledge, there's no way of knowing which quests will fail after a certain amount of time and which can wait until you have a spare few days.

Beyond that, this game has many bugs, unintuitive user interface, and a baffling relationship with the D&D alignment system. It is extremely bizarre to me, for instance, that a pair of lovers who care deeply about each other would just shrug off one of them being good and one of them being evil. I don't see how any healthy relationship could survive when one of the things they disagree on is "murder is wrong".

That being said, the art and music are lovely and the characters come to life in the game's stronger moments. I don't buy the level of camaraderie they supposedly share with each other by the end (it would make more sense to me that most of them simply tolerate one another due to their relationship to the player character), but they are fully realized in their own moments, and in the conversations you share with them. The story has many archetypal beats and it feels very aimless during its middle portions. The reveal of how all these disparate events are related probably could have been dropped earlier for a stronger narrative, I think. But overall, it is a story of reclaiming what is lost, and banding together even when it doesn't make sense. And there are many moments where you really feel your choices playing out throughout the land and over the years, in particular a gift you receive early on in the game comes in handy at a very late chapter of the story, which made for a great moment in my play-through.

Overall, I can only really recommend this gamer to people who are fans of the Pathfinder role-playing system. But for everyone else, I say avoid this absolute time vampire!

[h2]Review after 3 Hours: Deep Pathfinder System, Annoying Prologue & Characters[/h2]
I really wanted to like this game. It clearly offers a deep and faithful implementation of the Pathfinder ruleset - all the feats, skills, spells, and checks are there, and the interface for reviewing character builds and progression is nicely done.

What completely turned me off, though, was the prologue and its characters. The game forces on you an obnoxious female Bard companion who insists on chronicling your adventures because “you’re destined to be a hero.” That alone was grating, but what really broke it for me was discovering that the [i]journal interface[/i] is written entirely from the Bard’s perspective  meaning this irritating character is tied directly to the game’s core UI.  I don’t know if that changes later, but it was enough to stop me right there.

The setup also leans hard on clichés,  a sweaty, bloodthirsty female barbarian, a snarky evil sorcerer you have to tolerate for no reason, and the usual “heroes summoned to a mansion for a shared quest” trope. It all felt predictable, and the so-called twist in the prologue didn’t help.

That said, there’s no denying the game looks good for its genre and has a lot of mechanical depth. Fans of the Pathfinder ruleset will probably enjoy it. But for me, the writing, tone, and character presentation in the early game were just too off-putting.

The scale and scope of this game is impressive. I was SO excited when I booted it up to experience a new RPG system even if it was going to be a jankier older game.

And then, I came to learn that the jankiness of this game is entirely based on the absolutely, mindnumbingly frog-brained decision to make every single simulated dice roll impossible to hit. I am not joking when I say that [b] it took me 30 minutes to fight a pack of 6 level 2 spiders [/b] which suddenly activated their trap card, whacked me 4 times, killed me entire party, and then I had to spend another 30 minutes refighting (and that time the rng favored me at least).

The first step is the hardest - that's how I can sum up Owlcat's first game. So much about Kingmaker is just straight up bad and the only thing that keeps me going is admiration towards Owlcat being bold enough to actually make a game in Pathfinder ruleset. 

I wanna be perfectly clear - this system sucks ass. Don't listen to sychopants and nerds, it's simply bad and there's no way around it. Like I genuinely cannot believe someone could willingly gaslit themselves into playing this abomination of a ruleset. It's like sniffing your own farts and being proud about it. Everything about Pathfinder is atrociously bloated, overcomplicated and just simply not fun. This system inherits everything that is objectively bad about DnD: extremely long lists of worthless feats, stacking +1 buffs from every possible source as the prime instrument of buildcrafting, skills that are mostly meaningless outside very specific circumstancees, godawful spell slot system paired with mandated resting. I cannot stress enough how inherently anti-fun the spell slot system is - it's literally a warcrime DnD have commited against the whole TTRPG world. It's basically the equivalent of your parents gifting you a cool toy for Christmas yet allowing you only 5 minutes per day to play with it. But not only Pathfinder copies all the wrong things DnD does, it doubles down on bloating every aspect of it. Every rule has dozens of exceptions, instead of one dispel - there are dozens of different effect-specific dispels, literally hundreds of weapon-types that literally do the exact same damage. If you haven't guessed already yeah, I really do dislike Pathfinder system. And what's even worse, the game really does an awful job of explaining it.

If you have ever played an Owlcat game before - you can already guess what kind of encounter/boss design Kingmaker has. Imagine a DM that for whatever reason hates the party so badly, they will stop at nothing in order to humiliate and wipe them out. That's how it works in general in Kingmaker. Overinflated DCs for every mob in the game, attacks that deal permanent stat damage, bosses that spam disables, mobs spawning behind your back to disrupt your positioning. Some call it a "challenge", but honestly it feels like cheating. You can overcome it if you really want to, but it doesn't make it more fair or balanced. But the worst offender gameplay wise is time limits - time limits everywhere. Some are obvious, some are not, some are just a side-quest lost - no big deal, some can ruin your whole game potentially wasting dozens of hours of gameplay. I hope you like unintentionally failing like literally half of your quests because you were forced to stay in your capital jerking off your advisor for two weeks straight - because it will happen and it will happen a lot. 

The most succinct summary i can give to Kingmaker is that I literally had more fun building villages in the kingdom simulator part than playing the game itself. Thus, I can't really recommend it to anyone other than DnD nerds. Go play WOTR or Rogue Trader. This game has 25% of negative reviews for a reason.

Hack of their head in a execution. In either the cases of hacking off their head or scolding them the game will punish you for making decisive actions like this, not with a alignment shift, but also because you eliminated the super cool character some writer wrote up by having the penalities be rather harsh now that their gone. In many cases these characters personal quests tie into your kingdoms prosperity to in alot of cases, so rather than just having the consequence of not getting to  use your NPC companion or learn their full story, but your kingdom is somehow dragged down a level or two. Also good luck on making a replacement for that companion you dismiss or kill if there also a  advisor for you, they often are the best in slot and you get a inherent penalty for using multiple custom characters, unless you were to mod their stats to reduce the mercenary debuff given which is only really there to enforce you using the NPCs the game gives you for a party,  which helps speak to the confidence the writers have in their own work or the agency of a player.

Companions are in general terribly written, unlikable or subversive or traitorous for characters that really have no excuse for doing these things other than to annoy the player. If the game basically didnt make it mandatory to use most of them as advisors I would have dismissed or killed many of them.

The game is also extremely buggy in Acts 3 & 4 to the point where I would have to go back on saves made a hour or two before a decision (thank god i save fairly regularly) or download toybox to fix the initiation for quests after looking them up and realizing that they were bugged and not working properly. 

Gameplay itself is quite alright, Pathfinder has always been a exceptional ttrpg system and translates well into the game barring a few hiccups that can be expected for any CRPG or a system with alot of crunch and expansive as Pathfinder, which i do not blame the dev for its just naturally going to happen and they did well keeping the spirit of the tabletop into combat for better or for worse. This does mean in some cases your expected to min-max a bit if you want to be able to get through tougher challenges or to advance without wanting to rip your hair out, but you have enough wiggle room to make variant characters and not have to level the same 4 skills to max every level up if you know what your doing.

Hopefully future titles (or an update) improve controller support and make the tutorials more accessible — because the world and style seem great otherwise
